description: From Afrikaans bok (“buck; goat”) and English wagon. The Oxford English Dictionary suggests a possible derivation from Middle English bouk (“belly”) or Old English buc (“buck; deer”).

entries.meaning: (South Africa) A strong wagon with a frame over the wheels used for hauling goods.
examples: Upon each loaded buck-wagon, drawn by any sort of animals, not exceeding sixteen in number £0.17s.6d.

entries.meaning: (US) A buckboard; a wagon for personal transport as well as transporting goods.
examples: ...while on the remaining days of the week a two-horse buck-wagon or hack is used.
